attack-object.name: Trusted Relationship
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can isolate portions of network that do not require network-wide access, limiting some attackers that leverage trusted relationships such as remote access for vendor maintenance. Coverage partial, Temporal Immediate.

attack-object.name: Man-in-the-Middle
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can be used to limit access to network infrastructure and resources that can be used to reshape traffic or otherwise produce MiTM conditions.

attack-object.name: Data from Configuration Repository
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can limit attackers access to configuration repositories such as SNMP management stations, or to dumps of client configurations from common management ports.

attack-object.name: Pre-OS Boot
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: Provides protection coverage for only one sub-technique partially (booting from remote devies ala TFTP boot) resulting in an overall score of Minimal.

attack-object.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: NSG can minimize alternative protocols allowed to communicate externally.

attack-object.name: Exploitation of Remote Services
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can be used to restrict access to remote services to minimum necessary.

attack-object.name: Remote Services
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control provides partial protection for all of its sub-techniques and procedure examples resulting in an overall score of Partial.

attack-object.name: Software Deployment Tools
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can be used to limit access to critical network systems such as software deployment tools.

attack-object.name: External Remote Services
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can be used to restrict direct access to remote service gateways and concentrators that typically accompany external remote services.  This can be circumvented though if an adversary is able to compromise a trusted host and use it to access the external remote service. This results in an overall partial (coverage) score.

One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can be used to isolate sensitive domains to limit discovery.

One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.

Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can be used to restrict access to trusted networks and protocols.

attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can restrict traffic to standard ports and protocols.

attack-object.name: Endpoint Denial of Service
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control provides partial protection for a majority of this control's sub-techinques and procedure examples resulting in overall score of Partial.

attack-object.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can be used to limit traffic between systems and enclaves to minimum necessary for example via a zero-trust strategy.

attack-object.name: Network Denial of Service
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can be used to restrict access to endpoints and thereby mitigate low-end network DOS attacks.

attack-object.name: Proxy
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can restrict ports and inter-system / inter-enclave connections as described by the Proxy related sub-techniques although it doesn't provide protection for domain-fronting.  It furthermore provides partial protection of this technique's procedure examples resulting in an overall Partial score.

attack-object.name: Remote Access Software
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control can be used to restrict network communications to protect sensitive enclaves that may mitigate some of the procedure examples of this technique.

attack-object.name: Traffic Signaling
attack-object.comments: Note: one can employ Application Security Groups (ASG) in Network Security Group (NSG) rules to map  rules to workloads etc. Not scoring ASG as a separate control. One can employ Adaptive Network Hardening (ANH)  to generate recommended NSG rules based on traffic, known trusted configuration, threat intelligence, and other inidcators of compromise. Not scoring ANH as a separate control.
attack-object.score-comment: This control provides partial protection for this technique's sub-techniques and procedure examples resulting in an overall Partial score.  Other variations that trigger a special response, such as executing a malicous task are not mitigated by this control.
